newsitem.title: USA: Heavy rains headed to central Illinois.
newsitem.headline: Heavy rains headed to central Illinois.

text.p: Heavy rains were expected in central Illinois Wednesday, compounding flooding problems on the Illinois and Rock rivers, meteorologists said.

"We do have another rain storm moving in and it looks like it's taking aim right at the Illinois River," said Joel Burgio, meteorologist with Weather Services Corp. "We're projecting 0.50 to 2.00 inches with locally heavier. The heaviest rainfall will be between Peoria and Springfield."
Freese-Notis meteorologist Craig Solberg said central Illinois can expect up to two inches of rain in the next 24 to 36 hours.
"It (flooding potential) looks pretty severe," Solberg said. "The weather pattern looks active for the next 10 days with above-normal rainfall expected."
Burgio said runoff can be more severe at this time of year because there is less vegetation to soak up ground moisture and cold temperatures limit evaporation.

"Almost all of the rain that falls goes into the rivers," Burgio said. "In the summertime a good portion of it is either absorbed into the soils and used by the vegetation or evaporated because of the hotter temperatures."
Mid-range forecasts suggested storms would move across Illinois about every third day, said Fred Gesser, chief forecaster with Weather Express Inc.
"The models show another storm system Saturday, bringing another 0.50 to 2.00 inches of precipitation to Illinois," Gesser said. "It looks like it will be in the form of rain."
He added, "Temperatures are going to be mild enough with these systems that where there is snow, it's going to be melting. It's (flooding) going to be worse before it gets better."
National Weather Service's six- to 10-day outlook updated Tuesday predicted above-normal temperatures for Illinois with above-normal precipitation in the eastern half of the state.
